content: The "Neutral Cost Recovery Act for Small Business" may be cited as the short title. It includes increased expensing for small businesses. The "Neutral Cost Recovery Act for Small Business" includes increased expensing for small businesses. Amendment to section 179(b) of the Internal Revenue Code sets a $75,000 limit on aggregate cost for any taxable year, with a reduction based on property basis under section 168(k). The Neutral Cost Recovery Act for Small Business increases expensing limits. Section 179(b) of the Internal Revenue Code raises the phaseout threshold to $325,000. Section 179(d) defines section 179 property to include tangible property and computer software. The Neutral Cost Recovery Act for Small Business increases expensing limits for tangible property and computer software that is section 1245 property acquired for use in a trade or business. It excludes property described in section 50(b) and air conditioning or heating. The Neutral Cost Recovery Act for Small Business increases expensing limits for tangible property and computer software used in a trade or business, excluding certain types of property. Inflation adjustments are made to dollar amounts for taxable years after 2003. The dollar amounts in paragraphs (1) and (2) will be increased beginning in a calendar year after 2003 based on the cost-of-living adjustment determined for that year. The dollar amounts in paragraphs (1) and (2) will be rounded to the nearest multiple of $1,000 and $10,000 respectively if they are not already multiples of those amounts. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2002. Taxpayers can revoke an election under paragraph (1) with respect to any property, but once made, the revocation is irrevocable. If a dollar amount is not a multiple of $10,000, it will be rounded to the nearest multiple of $10,000. SEC. 3. NEUTRAL COST RECOVERY DEPRECIATION ADJUSTMENT FOR CERTAIN PROPERTY PLACED IN SERVICE AFTER DECEMBER 31, 2003. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to allow for a deduction adjustment to equivalent expensing for certain property placed in service after December 31, 2003. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 allows for a deduction adjustment to equivalent expensing for certain property placed in service after December 31, 2003. The deduction under section 179 for such property is determined by substituting '150 percent' for '200 percent' in the case of property to which the 200 percent declining balance method would otherwise apply. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 allows for a deduction adjustment to equivalent expensing for certain property placed in service after December 31, 2003. The deduction is determined by multiplying the amount without regard to certain factors by the applicable neutral cost recovery ratio for the taxable year. The ratio is calculated by dividing the gross domestic product. The deduction is determined by dividing the gross domestic product deflator for the quarter when the property was placed in service by the deflator for the quarter ending in the taxable year. The deduction is calculated by dividing the GDP deflator for the quarter when the property was placed in service by 1.035 to the power of the number of full years since the property was placed in service. The applicable neutral cost recovery ratio for certain property is calculated based on the GDP deflator for the quarter when the property was placed in service, ensuring it is never less than 1 and rounded to the nearest \1/1000\. The applicable neutral cost recovery ratio for certain property is determined without regard to specific subparagraphs, and the gross domestic product deflator is used for calculations. The subsection provides rules for property elections, exemptions, and deductions without affecting basis or recapture. The additional amount determined under this section shall not affect the adjusted basis of any property or interest in a pass-thru entity, and it is not considered a depreciation deduction for sections 1245 and 1250. The term 'pass-thru entity' includes regulated investment companies, real estate investment trusts, S corporations, partnerships, estates, trusts, and common trust funds. Minimum tax treatment is amended in section 56(a) of the Code. Minimum Tax Treatment is amended in section 56(a) of the Code to include the use of a neutral cost recovery ratio for property under section 168(k) placed in service after December 31, 2003. The neutral cost recovery ratio for property placed in service is determined under section 168(k) and applies to taxable years after December 31, 2003. This provision does not apply if there is an election in effect to not have section 168(k) apply. The text discusses amendments to various sections of the tax code regarding the neutral cost recovery deduction and coordination with depreciation limitations on certain automobiles. The amendments include changes to section 56(g)(4), section 280F(a)(1)(B), and section 168(k).
